list.title: Question 1
list.content: - Sketch the graph of $y = (x-2)^2-4|x-2|-1$, for $-3 \leq x \leq 7$. [3] - Hence, or otherwise, solve the equation $(x-2)^2-4|x-2|-1 = 0$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- If we sketch the graph of $y = (x-2)^2-4|x-2|-1$ for
$-3 \leq x \leq 7$, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d07f4430-c59c-44f9-a842-b167cf69a868/images/3d5a866f-0959-48f4-941c-c6486f9873ca/0ab2fa40cd74cdb2dd31cab2dedea2512bfb0bd0.svg)


- The solutions to the equation $(x-2)^2-4|x-2|-1 = 0$ are the
$x$-coordinates of the points C and D.
  Hence the solutions to the equation are
$\answer{x \approx -2.24,\hspace{0.25em}6.24}$

list.title: Question 2
list.content: Consider the function $f(x)=\dfrac{e^x-e^{-x}}{2}$, $x\in \mathbb{R}$. - Show that $f$ is an odd function. [2] Now, consider the function $g$ given by $g(x) = \dfrac{x^4+2}{2x}$ , $x\in \mathbb{R}, x \neq 0$. - By considering the graph of $y=f(x)-g(x)$, solve $f(x)>g(x)$ for $x\in \mathbb{R}$. [4]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $f(-x)$, we get

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  f(-x) &= \dfrac{e^{-x}-e^{-(-x)}}{2} \\[10pt]
  &= \dfrac{e^{-x}-e^{x}}{2} \\[10pt]
  &= -\dfrac{e^{x}-e^{-x}}{2} \\[10pt]
  &= -f(x) \\[-8pt]
  \end{align*}
  $$

  $\answer{\text{Therefore, $f(x)$ is an odd function}}$
- If $f(x)-g(x)>0$, then $f(x)>g(x)$. Using G.D.C., we get
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/cf76b687-c4cf-4f02-a51c-0d0d8c929218/images/0ae01be6-8c62-4dff-b5d4-bdc1c895874f/AA930a.PNG)


  We see that $f(x)-g(x)>0$ for $-4.55 < x < 0$ and $x > 4.55$.
  Therefore $f(x)>g(x)$ over the intervals
$\answer{-4.55 < x < 0 \text{ and } x > 4.55}$

list.title: Question 3
list.content: Let $f(x) = \dfrac{4-ax}{5x - 2}$. - Write down the equation of the vertical asymptote of the graph of $y = f(x)$.[1] The line $y = -1.4$ is a horizontal asymptote to the graph of $y = f(x)$. - Find the value of $a$.[2] - The line $y = x - c$, where $c \in \mathbb{R}^+$, intersects the graph of $y = \big|f(x)\big|$ at exactly one point. Find the possible values of $c$. [4]
list.markScheme:
- Solving the equation $5x-2=0$, we have $\tcbhighmath{x = \dfrac{2}{5}}$
- The horizontal asymptote will be equal to $\displaystyle\lim_{x \to \pm \infty}f(x)$. We have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \displaystyle\lim_{x \to \pm \infty}f(x) &= \displaystyle\lim_{x \to \pm \infty}\dfrac{4-ax}{5x-2} \\[8pt]
  -1.4 &= -\dfrac{a}{5} \\[8pt]
  &\hspace{-0.5em}\tcbhighmath{a=7}
  \end{align*}
  $$

- If we draw the graph of $y = |f(x)|$ [by using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d38234a3-2406-4a17-ad72-c2dccf3aebd1/images/423ecaf7-2110-4ebe-8d00-cb3ef860ab02/aa1027a.PNG)


  A line of the form $y = x - c$ where $c \in \mathbb{R}^+$ has a gradient of $m=1$ and a $y$-intercept that is less than zero. The following diagram shows the graph of $y=x$, which represents an absolute upper limit for the $y$-intercept.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d38234a3-2406-4a17-ad72-c2dccf3aebd1/images/66fa47d7-6be3-4bd7-bfc8-104af16f2d66/aa1027b.PNG)


  The line $y=x$ intersects the graph of $y = \big|f(x)\big|$ at three points.
  The following diagram shows the graph of $y=x-0.571$, which passes through the point A$(0.571,0)$ and has a $y$-intercept of $-0.571$.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d38234a3-2406-4a17-ad72-c2dccf3aebd1/images/47bdebc2-8242-44ff-8e71-2793f3857f00/aa1027c.PNG)


  The line $y=x-0.571$ intersects the graph of $y = \big|f(x)\big|$ at two points. Any line of gradient $m=1$ and $y$-intercept of less than $-0.571$ will intersect the graph of $y = \big|f(x)\big|$ exactly once.
  Therefore, $\tcbhighmath{c > 0.571}$

list.title: Question 4
list.content: Consider the function $f(x) = x^2\arcsin(x)$, for $-1 \leq x \leq 1$. - Sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$. [3] - Write down the range of $f$. [2] - Solve the inequality $\left|x^2\arcsin(x)\right| > 0.5$. [3]

list.title: Question 5
list.content: A population of endangered snow leopards, $P$, can be modelled by the equation $$ \begin{aligned} P_t = P_0e^{kt},\end{aligned} $$ where $P_0$ is the initial population, and $t$ is measured in years. - After one year, it is estimated that $\dfrac{P_1}{P_0} = 0.93$. - Find the value of $k$. - Interpret the meaning of the value of $k$. [3] - Find the least number of whole years for which $\dfrac{P_t}{P_0} < 0.50$. [5]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Substituting $t = 1$ in the equation $P_t = P_0e^{kt}$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    P_1 &= P_0e^{k(1)} \hspace{1em} \\[6pt]
    \dfrac{P_1}{P_0} &= e^k \\[6pt]
    \hspace{0.1em} 0.93 &= e^k \\[11pt]
    k &= \ln 0.93 \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$


    $$
    \hspace{0.8em} \answer{k \approx -0.0726}
    $$

  - $\answer{\text{The rate at which the population of leopards exponentially decrease}}$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{P_t}{P_0} &< 0.50 \\[8pt]
  e^{-0.0726t} &< 0.50 \\[12pt]
  -0.0726t &< \ln 0.50 \\[6pt]
  t &> -\dfrac{\ln 0.50}{0.0726} \\[8pt]
  t &> 9.55 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the least number of whole years
for which $\dfrac{P_t}{P_0} < 0.50$ is
$\answer{t = 10}$

list.title: Question 6
list.content: Consider the graphs of $y = -\dfrac{1}{2}|x|$ and $y = 2|x| - a$, where $a \in \mathbb{Z}^+$. - Sketch the graphs on the same set of axes. [2] - Given that the graphs enclose a region of area 40 square units, find the value of $a$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- If we sketch the graphs of $y = -\dfrac{1}{2}|x|$ and
$y = 2|x| - a$, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e1f7ba47-5c7f-4483-baa8-4c9fa89f8efb/images/52d9876b-801d-4d99-bd5b-65f532bdeb39/68ec0f82b42dd94d75c48aa4929409d0a553c4d8.svg)


- The two lines in the $4$th quadrant intersect when

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{9.4em} -\dfrac{1}{2}x &= 2x -a \hspace{3em} [\text{since $x > 0$}] \\[6pt]
  -x &= 4x - 2a \\[10pt]
  2a &= 5x \\[6pt]
  x &= \dfrac{2a}{5}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the area enclosed between
the two graphs is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  2\bigg[\dfrac{1}{2}(\text{base}\times\text{height})\bigg] &= 2\bigg[\dfrac{1}{2}\Big(a\times\dfrac{2a}{5}\Big)\bigg] \hspace{2.2em} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{2a^2}{5}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, given that the area is $40$
square units, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{2a^2}{5} &= 40 \\[6pt]
  a^2 &= 100 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{0.7em} \answer{a = 10}
  $$

list.title: Question 7
list.content: Let $f(x) = \dfrac{9-12x}{cx - 20}$, for $x \neq \dfrac{20}{c}$, where $c \neq 0$. - The line $x = 5$ is a vertical asymptote to the graph of $y = f(x)$. - Find the value of $c$. - Write down the equation of the horizontal asymptote to the graph of $y = f(x)$.[4] - The line $y = h$, where $h \in \mathbb{R}$, intersects the graph of $y = \big|f(x)\big|$ at exactly one point. Find the possible values of $h$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Using the equation of the vertical asymptote, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    &= 0 \hspace{8.6em} \\[6pt]
    5c - 20 &= 0 \\[6pt]
    5c &= 20 \\[4pt]
    &\hspace{-0.67em} \answer{c = 4}
    \end{aligned}
    $$

  - $\answer{y = -3}$

- If we draw the graph of $y = |f(x)|$ [by using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f3658e86-b348-445b-bade-3ea93bdc0f36/images/7c07f0a2-c2b1-440d-be6c-385ece839f36/05e9ba9d7a31d35d6e66b11e5f0ab06197d7db87.svg)


  A line of the form $y = h$ can intersect the graph of $y = |f(x)|$
exactly at one point either at A or at B, as shown on the diagram
above.
  Hence we find
$\answer{h = 0,\hspace{0.25em}3}$

list.title: Question 8
list.content: - Sketch the curve $y = -\left|\dfrac{5}{x-2}\right|$ and line $y = -x - 4$ on the same axes, clearly indicating any $x$ and $y$ intercepts and any asymptotes. [3] - Find the exact solutions to the equation $x + 4 = \dfrac{5}{|x-2|}$. [5]
list.markScheme:
- Let $f(x) = -\left|\dfrac{5}{x-2}\right|$ where $x \in \mathbb{R}$,
$x \neq 2$.
  Since $f(x) < 0$ for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$, $x \neq 2$, the curve
$y = f(x)$ has no $x$-intercepts.
  Evaluating $y = f(x)$ for $x = 0$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} y &= f(0) \\[12pt]
  &= -\left|-\dfrac{5}{2}\right| \\[6pt]
  &= -\dfrac{5}{2}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the point A$(0,-5/2)$ is the
$y$-intercept of the curve $y = f(x)$.
  We have

  $$
  \lim_{x \rightarrow\pm\infty} f(x) = 0 \hspace{3.9em}
  $$

  Hence the $x$-axis is a horizontal asymptote of the curve
$y = f(x)$.
  The denominator of $f$ is zero when $x = 2$. Hence the line $x = 2$
is a vertical asymptote of the curve $y = f(x)$.
  The $x$ and $y$ intercepts of the line $y = -4-x$ are B$(-4,0)$ and
C$(0,-4)$.
  If we sketch the curve $y = f(x)$ and line $y = -x - 4$ on the same
axes, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3ce10e6d-6009-49da-a002-42ae1d773968/images/2248acaa-10a6-4043-b8a6-84823cf01ad6/38ce371d4e9621963b29074adf6413c8b9f71c7c.svg)


- If we solve the equation $x + 4 = \dfrac{5}{|x-2|}$ for $x < 2$, we
find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  x + 4 &= -\dfrac{5}{x-2} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $x - 2 < 0$}] \\[9pt]
  \hspace{7.7em} (x+4)(x-2) &= -5 \\[12pt]
  x^2 + 2x - 8 &= -5 \\[12pt]
  x^2 + 2x - 3 &= 0 \\[13pt]
  (x + 3)(x - 1) &= 0 \\[13pt]
  x &= -3,\hspace{0.25em} 1\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we simplify the equation
$x + 4 = \dfrac{5}{|x-2|}$ for $x > 2$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  x + 4 &= \dfrac{5}{x-2} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $x - 2 > 0$}] \\[9pt]
  \hspace{10em} (x+4)(x-2) &= 5 \\[13pt]
  x^2 + 2x - 8 &= 5 \\[13pt]
  x^2 + 2x - 13 &= 0\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the quadratic
formula, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{12em} x &= \dfrac{-2+\sqrt{2^2-4(1)(-13)}}{2} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $x > 2$}] \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{-2+2\sqrt{14}}{2} \\[12pt]
  &= -1 + \sqrt{14} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the
exact solutions to the equation $\text{\(x + 4 = \dfrac{5}{|x-2|}\)}$ are  $\answer{-3,\hspace{0.25em}1,\hspace{0.25em}\textstyle -1 + \sqrt{14}}$

list.title: Question 9
list.content: The function $f$ is defined by $f(x) = 1+ \dfrac{4x}{x+3}$, for $x \neq -3$. - Sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$, indicating clearly any asymptotes and points of intersection with the $x$ and $y$ axes. [4] - Find an expression for $f^{-1}$. [4] - Find all values of $x$ for which $f(x) = f^{-1}(x)$. [3] - Solve the inequality $|f(x)| < 2$. [4] - Solve the inequality $f(|x|) < 2$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- If we solve the equation $f(x) = 0$ for $x$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  1+ \dfrac{4x}{x+3} &= 0 \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{5x+3}{x+3} &= 0 \\[11pt]
  5x + 3 &= 0 \\[10pt]
  x &= -\dfrac{3}{5} \hspace{2.1em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the point
P$(-3/5,0)$ is the $x$-intercept of the graph of $y = f(x)$.
  Evaluating $y = f(x)$ for $x = 0$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2em} y &= f(0) \\[6pt]
  &= 1\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the point Q$(0,1)$ is the $y$-intercept of
the graph of $y = f(x)$.
  We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \lim_{x \rightarrow\pm\infty} f(x) &= 1 + \dfrac{4}{1} \hspace{3.7em} \\[6pt]
  &= 5\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the line $y = 5$ is a horizontal asymptote
of the graph of $y = f(x)$.
  The denominator of $f$ is zero when $x = -3$. Hence the line
$x = -3$
is a vertical asymptote of the graph of $y = f(x)$.
  If we sketch of the graph of $y = f(x)$, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b02f9456-fc87-4d72-8046-b8ad6f17fd88/images/80e5d1bc-25e1-48da-ad0b-cf11c4df076c/a4ee5024679811f4302b4cf52d17f68170c60827.svg)


- If we solve the equation $(f\circ f^{-1})(x) = x$ for
$y = f^{-1}(x)$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(f^{-1}(x)) &= x \hspace{3.7em}  \\[8pt]
  f\left(y\right) &= x\end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.7em} 1+ \dfrac{4y}{y+3} &= x \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{5y+3}{y+3} &= x \\[10pt]
  5y+3 &= xy+3x \\[16pt]
  (5-x)y &= 3x-3 \\[10pt]
  y &= \dfrac{3x-3}{5-x} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence an expression for
$f^{-1}$ is
$\answer{f^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{3x-3}{5-x}}$
- If we solve the equation $f(x) = f^{-1}(x)$ for $x$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(x) &= f^{-1}(x) \\[9pt]
  1 + \dfrac{4x}{x+3} &= \dfrac{3x-3}{5-x} \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{5x+3}{x+3} &= \dfrac{3x-3}{5-x} \\[10pt]
  (5x+3)(5-x) &= (3x-3)(x+3) \\[12pt]
  \hspace{1.6em} 25x - 5x^2 + 15 -3x &= 3x^2 + 9x -3x - 9 \\[12pt]
  -8x^2 + 16x + 24 &= 0\end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  x^2 - 2x - 3 &= 0 \\[12pt]
  (x+1)(x-3) &= 0 \hspace{4em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{3.6em} \answer{x = -1,\hspace{0.25em}3}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  
  \hspace{8.1em} \begin{array}{rcccl}
  && |f(x)| &<& 2 \\[13pt]
  -2 &<& f(x) &<& 2 \\[12pt]
  f^{-1}(-2) &<& x &<& f^{-1}(2) \hspace{2em} [\text{since $f^{-1}(f(x)) = x$}]
  \end{array}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Evaluating $y = f^{-1}(x)$ for $x = -2$,
we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.4em} f^{-1}(-2) &= \dfrac{3(-2)-3}{5-(-2)} \\[3pt]
  &= -\dfrac{9}{7} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Evaluating $y = f^{-1}(x)$ for
$x = 2$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.2em} f^{-1}(2) &= \dfrac{3(2)-3}{5-2}  \hspace{0.8em} \\[8pt]
  &= 1 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the set of solutions to the inequality
$|f(x)| < 2$ is
$\answer{-\frac{9}{7}<x<1}$
- If we solve the inequality $f(|x|) < 2$ for $|x|$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.5em} 1+ \dfrac{4|x|}{|x|+3} &< 2 \\[5pt]
  \dfrac{4|x|}{|x|+3} &< 1 \\[10pt]
  4|x| &< |x|+3 \\[16pt]
  3|x| &< 3 \\[16pt]
  |x| &< 1 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the set of solutions to the
inequality $f(|x|) < 2$ is
$\answer{-1<x<1}$

list.title: Question 10
list.content: - Solve the inequality $x^2 \geq 2x + 3$. [2] - Use mathematical induction to prove that $2^n > n^2 - 2$ for all $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$, $n \geq 3$.[6]
list.markScheme:
- If we draw the graphs of $y = x^2$ and $y = 2x + 3$ [by using
G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2657c2a5-86af-44db-8be4-bfd4d027e790/images/2ce2fde1-d607-4fa0-9109-01ca871a4538/8559be520206e999f46f83d313584ee1a94282b7.svg)


  Using the $x$-coordinates of A and B, we see that the graph of
$y = x^2$ is above the graph of $y = 2x+3$ when $x < -1$ and
$x > 3$, and the graphs intersect at $x = -1,3$.
  Hence the solution set to the inequality $x^2 \geq 2x+3$ is
$\answer{(-\infty,-1] \cup [3, \infty)}$
- Let P$(n)$ be the following statement:

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{7.2em} 2^n &> n^2 - 2 \hspace{3em} [\text{for $n\geq3$}] \hspace{1.9em}\end{aligned}
  $$


Using mathematical induction, we will prove that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$, $n \geq 3$.
Base case. For $n = 3$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
2^3 = 8 &> 3^2 - 2 = 7\end{aligned}
$$

Hence P$(3)$ holds.
Inductive hypothesis. We assume that P$(k)$ holds for some
$k \geq 3$. In other words, we assume that

$$
\begin{aligned}
2^k &> k^2 - 2 \qref{(IH)}\end{aligned}
$$

for some $k \geq 3$.
Inductive step: To show that P$(k+1)$ holds, we need to
show that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{1.5em} 2^{k+1} &> (k+1)^2 - 2 \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

From the
left hand side of the inequality $(1)$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{6.8em} 2^{k+1} &= 2\cdot2^k \\[6pt]
&>2\hspace{0.05em}[k^2 - 2] \hspace{3em} [\text{by (IH)}] \\[6pt]
&= k^2 + [k^2 - 4] \\[6pt]
[\text{by part (a)}] \hspace{3em} &\geq 2k+3 + [k^2 - 4] \\[6pt]
&= [k^2 + 2k + 1] - 2 \\[6pt]
&= (k+1)^2 - 2 \end{aligned}
$$

Hence P$(k+1)$ holds as well.
Conclusion. P$(3)$ holds, and for every $k \geq 3$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that
P$(n)$ holds for all $\text{\(n\hspace{-0.2em}\in\hspace{-0.2em}\mathbb{Z}^+\hspace{-0.2em},\hspace{0.05em}n\hspace{-0.2em}\geq\hspace{-0.2em}3\)}$.

list.title: Question 11
list.content: Let $f(x) = x^4 - 0.4\hspace{0.05em}x^3 - 2.85\hspace{0.05em}x^2 + 0.9\hspace{0.05em}x + 1.35$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. - Find the solutions for $f(x) > 0$. [3] - For the graph of $y = f(x)$, - find the coordinates of local minimum and maximum points. - find the $x$-coordinates of the points of inflexion. [5] The domain of $f$ is now restricted to $[a,b]$ where $a, b \in \mathbb{R}^+$. - - Write down the smallest value of $a > 0$ and the largest value of $b > 0$ for which $f$ has an inverse. Give your answers correct to three significant figures. - For these values of $a$ and $b$, sketch the graphs of $y = f(x)$ and $y = f^{-1}(x)$ on the same set of axes, showing clearly the coordinates of the end points of each curve. - Solve $f^{-1}(x) = 0.5$. [6] Let $g(x) = \dfrac{2}{3}\sin(2x - 1) + \dfrac{1}{2}$, $\dfrac{1}{2} - \dfrac{\pi}{4} \leq x \leq \dfrac{1}{2} + \dfrac{\pi}{4}$. - - Find an expression for $g^{-1}$ and state its domain. - Solve $(f^{-1}\circ g)(x) < 0.5$. [8]
list.markScheme:
- If we sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$ [by using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b276ac45-671f-4c75-9dea-a3774fc53f67/images/44e18fcd-818c-481b-aabd-bbc35f210168/245a2a1979fce06233cc54e60878b1e96f11b9d1.svg)


  From the diagram, we see that $f$ is positive on the intervals
$(-\infty,-1.5)$, $(-0.6,1)$ and $(1.5,\infty)$, and negative on
$(-1.5,-0.6)$ and $(1,1.5)$.
  Hence the set of solutions to the inequality $f(x) > 0$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{(-\infty,-1.5)\cup(-0.6,1)\cup(1.5,\infty)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - From the diagram, we see that the graph of $y = f(x)$ has a
local
maximum at point A and local minimums at points B and C.
    Hence the coordinates of the local max and min points are

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \text{local max}:&\hspace{0.75em}\hspace{0.525em}\answer{(0.155, 1.42)} \vspace{0.75em} \\[10pt]
    \text{local min}:&\hspace{0.75em}\hspace{0.525em}\answer{(-1.13, -1.10)}\hspace{0.525em}\text{ and }\hspace{0.525em}\answer{(1.28, -0.322)}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    f(x) &= x^4 - 0.4x^3 - 2.85x^2 + 0.9x + 1.35 \\[6pt]
    f'(x) &= 4x^3 - 1.2x^2 - 5.7x + 0.9 \\[6pt]
    \hspace{1.5em} f''(x) &= 12x^2 - 2.4x - 5.7\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence, if we solve the equation
$f''(x) = 0$ for $x$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    12x^2 - 2.4x - 5.7 &= 0 \hspace{9.8em} \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$


    $$
    \hspace{12.95em} \answer{x \approx -0.596, \hspace{0.25em} 0.796} \hspace{2.5em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
    $$


- 
  - From the diagram, we see that $f$ is a bijection if its domain
is restricted to $[-1.13, 0.155]$ or $[0.155,1.28]$.
    As it is given that $a,b > 0$, hence $f$ has an inverse if
$\answer{a = 0.155}$
and  $\answer{b = 1.28}$
  - The graph of $y = f^{-1}(x)$ is the reflection of the graph of
$y = f(x)$ across the line $y = x$.
    Hence, if we sketch the graphs of $y = f(x)$ and $y = f^{-1}(x)$
on the same set of axes, we have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b276ac45-671f-4c75-9dea-a3774fc53f67/images/3ebbda78-45c5-40ce-9d82-70daf75779a2/524a320d1d2563d4a110444319e1f709eb5ee6c6.svg)


  - If we solve the equation $f^{-1}(x) = 0.5$ for $x$, we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    f(f^{-1}(x)) &= f(0.5) \hspace{4em} \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$


    $$
    \hspace{10.8em} \answer{x = 1.1} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $f(f^{-1}(x)) = x$}]
    $$


- 
  - Solving the equation $(g\circ g^{-1})(x) = x$ for
$y = g^{-1}(x)$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    g(g^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[14pt]
    g(y) &= x \\[10pt]
    \hspace{1.7em} \dfrac{2}{3}\sin(2y - 1) + \dfrac{1}{2} &= x \\[6pt]
    \dfrac{2}{3}\sin(2y - 1) &= \dfrac{2x-1}{2} \\[6pt]
    \sin(2y - 1) &= \dfrac{6x-3}{4} \\[4pt]
    2y - 1 &= \arcsin\bigg(\hspace{-0.05em}\dfrac{6x-3}{4}\bigg) \\[3pt]
    y &= \dfrac{1}{2}\arcsin\bigg(\hspace{-0.05em}\dfrac{6x-3}{4}\bigg) + \dfrac{1}{2} \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence an expression for $g^{-1}$ is
$\answer{g^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{1}{2}\arcsin\bigg(\hspace{-0.05em}\dfrac{6x-3}{4}\bigg) + \dfrac{1}{2}}$
The range of $g$ is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \left[-\dfrac{2}{3}+\dfrac{1}{2},\hspace{0.25em}\dfrac{2}{3}+\dfrac{1}{2}\right] = \left[-\dfrac{1}{6},\hspace{0.25em}\dfrac{7}{6}\right] \hspace{4.7em}\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the domain of $g^{-1}$ is
$\answer{\bigg[-\dfrac{1}{6},\dfrac{7}{6}\bigg]}$
  - Solving the inequality $(f^{-1}\circ g)(x) < 0.5$ for $x$, we
get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{9.5em} f^{-1}(g(x)) &< 0.5 \\[6pt]
    g(x) &> f(0.5) \hspace{3em} [\text{since $f$ is decreasing}] \\[6pt]
    g(x) &> 1.1 \\[5pt]
    x &> g^{-1}(1.1) \hspace{2em} [\text{since $g^{-1}$ is increasing}] \\[6pt]
    x &> 1.06\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the set of solutions to the
inequality $(f^{-1}\circ g)(x) < 0.5$ is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \answer{\left(1.06,\hspace{0.25em}\dfrac{1}{2} + \dfrac{\pi}{4}\right]} \hspace{2em}\end{aligned}
    $$

list.title: Question 12
list.content: Consider the function defined by $f(x) = (2x-6)\ln(x+3)+x$ for $x \in \mathbb{R}$, $x>p$. - Find the value of $p$. [2] - Find an expression for $f'(x)$. [3] The graph of $y=f(x)$ has no points of inflexion. - Determine if the graph of $y=f(x)$ is concave down or concave up over its domain. [3] The function $g$ is defined by $g(x)=3\ln\left(\dfrac{1}{x+3}\right)+x$, for $x\in \mathbb{R}$, $x>-3$. - Find an expression for $g'(x)$. [4] - Find the horizontal and vertical asymptotes of $g'(x)$.[2] - Find the exact value of the minimum of $y=g(x)$.[3] - Solve $f(x)-3$.[5]
list.markScheme:
- Due to the natural log term, $x+3>0$. Therefore
$\answer{ p=-3}$
- Differentiating $f$ with respect to $x$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f'(x) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\big[(2x-6)\ln(x+3)+x\big] \\[10pt]
  & \answer{=\dfrac{2x-6}{x+3}+2\ln(x+3)+1} \end{aligned}
  $$

- Differentiating $f'$ with respect to $x$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f''(x) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\left[\dfrac{2x-6}{x+3}+2\ln(x+3)+1\right] \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{(x+3)(2)-(2x-6)}{\left(x+3\right)^2} + \dfrac{2}{x+3} \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{2x+18}{(x+3)^2}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, over $x>-3$, we have $f''(x)>0$. Therefore,
$\answer{f \text{ is concave up}}$
- Differentiating $g$ with respect to $x$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  g'(x) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\left[3\ln\left(\dfrac{1}{x+3}\right)+x\right] \\[12pt]
  &=3(x+3)\left(-\dfrac{1}{(x+3)^2}\right)+1  \\[8pt]
  & =\dfrac{-3}{x+3}+1 \\[10pt] 
  & \answer{=\dfrac{x}{x+3}} \end{aligned}
  $$

- The denominator of $g'$ is zero when $x=-3$.
Hence,
$\answer{\text{the line \(x=-3\) is a vertical asymptote of the graph of \(y=g'(x)\)}}$
If we take the limit as $x$ tends to $\infty$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \lim_{x\to \infty} g'(x) &= \lim_{x\to \infty} \dfrac{x}{x+3}%\cdot \dfrac{\dfrac{1}{x}}{\dfrac{1}{x}}
  \\[8pt]
  & = \lim_{x\to \infty} \dfrac{1}{1+\dfrac{3}{x}\rule[-2mm]{0pt}{7.2mm}} \\[6pt]
  & = 1 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence,
$\answer{\text{the line \(y=1\) is a horizontal asymptote of the graph of \(y=g'(x)\)}}$
- From part (d) we obtain a stationary point at $x=0$.
The second derivative of $g$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  g''(x) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x} \left[\dfrac{x}{x+3}\right] \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{3}{(x+3)^2}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, $g''(x)>0$ which implies that at $x=0$ the function $g$
reaches its minimum. Therefore, the minimum value of $g$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  g(0) &= 3\ln\left(\dfrac{1}{3}\right)+0 \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= -3\ln(3)} \end{aligned}
  $$

- Using logarithm properties, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(x) &< g(x) \\[12pt]
  (2x-6)\ln(x+3) + x &< 3\ln\left(\dfrac{1}{x+3}\right) + x \\[12pt]
  (2x-6)\ln(x+3) &< -3\ln(x+3) \\[15pt]
  (2x-3)\ln(x+3) &< 0\end{aligned}
  $$

  Thus, we have two options

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \left[2x-3<0\enskip\&\enskip \ln(x+3)>0\right] &\text{  or  } \left[2x-3>0 \enskip\&\enskip \ln(x+3)<0\right] \\[12pt]
  \left[x<1.5\enskip\&\enskip\ln(x+3)>0\right]&\text{ or } \left[x>1.5\enskip\&\enskip \ln(x+3)<0\right] \\[12pt]
  x < 1.5\enskip & \&\enskip 1<x+3 \hspace{2em}[\text{since }\ln(x+3)>0\text{ for }x>1.5]\\[8pt]
  -2 <& \hspace{0.1em}x < 1.5 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Therefore,
$f(x)<g(x)$ over $\answer{-2 <  x < 1.5}$
